content: The Act titled "Justin Bailey Veterans Substance Use Disorders Prevention and Treatment Act of 2008" expands veterans substance use disorder programs. The Act "Justin Bailey Veterans Substance Use Disorders Prevention and Treatment Act of 2008" expands veterans substance use disorder programs by ensuring medical centers provide a full continuum of care for substance use disorders, including screening, detoxification, outpatient care, relapse prevention, counseling, residential treatment, and pharmacological treatment. The Act "Justin Bailey Veterans Substance Use Disorders Prevention and Treatment Act of 2008" expands veterans substance use disorder programs by providing a full continuum of care, including screening, detoxification, outpatient care, counseling, residential treatment, and pharmacological treatment. The Act also includes provisions for opioid substitution therapy, peer counseling coordination, short-term interventions, marital and family counseling, and outreach to veterans of Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom. The Act "Justin Bailey Veterans Substance Use Disorders Prevention and Treatment Act of 2008" expands veterans substance use disorder programs to ensure availability of treatment for all veterans in need. The Act "Justin Bailey Veterans Substance Use Disorders Prevention and Treatment Act of 2008" expands veterans substance use disorder programs to ensure equitable allocation of funding for care, treatment, and services without regard to veterans' residence locations. The Secretary must provide a detailed report on services provided under this section in the annual budget documents submitted to Congress. The Act "Justin Bailey Veterans Substance Use Disorders Prevention and Treatment Act of 2008" requires the Department to report data on veterans receiving care for substance use disorders at each medical facility, including screening, identification, and referrals for treatment. The Act "Justin Bailey Veterans Substance Use Disorders Prevention and Treatment Act of 2008" mandates reporting on veterans receiving care for substance use disorders at medical facilities, including availability of care, treatment, and services, reviewed by the Committee on Care of Severely Chronically Mentally Ill Veterans for assessment. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to fiscal years starting on or after October 1, 2009. Pilot program for internet-based substance use disorder treatment for veterans of Operation Iraqi Freedom and Operation Enduring Freedom. Congress finds that stigma surrounding mental health treatment deters some veterans from seeking help at military or VA facilities. Post-deployment mental health issues are prevalent among veterans, especially reservists transitioning to civilian life. Computer-based self-guided training is effective for psychological conditions, particularly for younger veterans from Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs initiated a pilot program in 2009 to provide veterans in rural areas with access to computer-based self-assessment, education, and treatment for substance use disorders through a secure Internet website. Participation in the program is voluntary for veterans who served in Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs launched a pilot program in 2009 to offer veterans in rural areas access to online self-assessment, education, and treatment for substance use disorders. The program is voluntary for veterans from Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom and ensures privacy of medical records. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs initiated a pilot program in 2009 to provide online resources for veterans in rural areas with substance use disorders. The program includes self-assessment, education, and treatment options, and ensures privacy of medical records. Additionally, the program considers similar projects by the Department of Defense for early diagnosis and treatment of mental health conditions. The pilot program is carried out in medical centers with Centers for Excellence for Substance Abuse Treatment and Education. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may enter into contracts with qualified entities to carry out a two-year pilot program for substance abuse treatment. $1,500,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2010 and 2011. A report to Congress is required six months after the pilot program's completion. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will submit a report to Congress on the two-year pilot program for substance abuse treatment, assessing its feasibility, cost savings, and benefits, along with recommendations for its continuation or expansion. SEC. 5. REPORT ON RESIDENTIAL MENTAL HEALTH CARE FACILITIES OF THE VETERANS HEALTH ADMINISTRATION. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must review all residential mental health care facilities within six months of this Act and submit a report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The report will include details on care availability and supervision in each Veterans Integrated Service Network. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will assess supervision, staff-to-patient ratios, medication procedures, appointment protocols, and make recommendations for improvements in residential mental health care facilities within six months of this Act. This Act is dedicated to Justin Bailey, a veteran who passed away in a Veterans Affairs facility while receiving care for post-traumatic stress disorder and substance use disorder after serving in Operation Iraqi Freedom.
